title: Understand the Initial Situation
text: You have a block of ice initially at a temperature of -5°C, and it's being put into water at a temperature of 25°C. The goal is to find the final temperature of the mixture.

title: Check Heat Exchange
text: Heat will be exchanged between the water and the ice until thermal equilibrium is reached. The heat lost by the water will be equal to the heat gained by the ice.

title: Calculate Heat Needed to Raise the Temperature of the Ice
text: Use the formula: $$q=cmΔT$$ where c = 36 $$\frac{J}{C \times mol}$$, $$m$$ = 50.0 g, and ΔT = 5°C. What is the heat required to raise the temperature of the ice from -5°C to 0°C?

title: Calculate Heat Required to Melt the Ice
text: Use the enthalpy of fusion: $$ΔH_{fus}=6.007\frac{kJ}{mol}$$. Calculate the heat required in Joules to melt 50.0 g of ice at 0°C to liquid water at 0°C.

title: Calculate the Heat Lost by Water
text: Use the specific heat capacity of water c = 75 $$\frac{J}{C \times mol}$$. Calculate the heat lost by the water when its temperature changes from 25°C to the final temperature.

title: Set Up the Equation for Heat Balance
text: Set up the equation such that the total heat gained by the ice equals the heat lost by the water. Solve for the final temperature.

title: Solve for Final Temperature
text: Using the heat balance equation, solve for the final temperature, $$T_f$$. Simplify and solve the equation algebraically.
